fact: The word 'quarantine' comes from the Italian 'quaranta giorni,' meaning 'forty days.'
The word 'robot' comes from a Czech word meaning 'forced labor.'
The word 'whiskey' comes from the Old Irish 'uisce beatha,' meaning 'water of life.'
The word 'nightmare' originally referred to a female spirit who suffocated sleepers.
The word 'cliché' comes from the sound of a printing plate, which was used to reproduce commonly used phrases.

The longest word in a major dictionary is 'pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis' (a lung disease).
The shortest complete sentence in English is 'I am.'
'Uncopyrightable' is the longest word without repeating any letter.
The most common English word is 'the.'
The least used letter in English is 'Z.'
The letter 'E' is the most frequently used in the English language.
The longest word typed using only the left hand on a QWERTY keyboard is 'stewardesses.'
The longest word typed using only the right hand is 'lollipop.'
The longest English word without a vowel is 'rhythms.'
'Queue' is pronounced the same way even if you remove the last four letters!
'Dreamt' is the only English word that ends with 'mt.'
'Bookkeeper' is the only English word with three consecutive double letters (oo, kk, ee).
The dot above 'i' and 'j' is called a 'tittle.'
There is no word that rhymes perfectly with 'orange,' 'silver,' or 'month.'
A pangram is a sentence that contains every letter of the alphabet, like 'The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.'
'Facetious' and 'abstemious' are two words that contain all vowels in order.
'Palindrome' words read the same forward and backward, like 'madam' and 'racecar.'
The English word with the most definitions is 'set.'
'Girl' used to mean 'a young person' regardless of gender.
'Nice' originally meant 'ignorant' or 'foolish' in Old English.

The word 'hello' became a common greeting only after the invention of the telephone.

The longest one-syllable word in English is 'screeched.'

The letter 'A' doesn't appear in the English number system until 'thousand.'
The longest palindrome in English is 'tattarrattat,' meaning a knock on a door.
The word 'news' comes from 'new' and was originally plural.
The phrase 'long time no see' comes from literal translations of Chinese and Native American languages.
The word 'goodbye' comes from 'God be with you.'
The word 'clue' originally meant a ball of yarn, referring to the story of Theseus in the labyrinth.
'Oxford comma' is the name for the comma before 'and' in a list, and it sparks many debates.
The word 'salary' comes from the Latin word for salt, as Roman soldiers were paid in salt.
The word 'pencil' comes from the Latin 'penicillus,' meaning 'little tail.'
